turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I wanted to talk to you about that.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Well, talk.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well not exactly, no; I got 'em sitting in the car, actually; I thought we might sell them back to the Greek, but I am having a bit of a problem getting hold of him.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: When the old bastard is not playing cards he's chasing a thousand debts that ill-fated individuals owe for an array of reasons.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Sex and sleaze and antique shotguns are all deep and dear in Harry's stone cold heart.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: The odds are one hundred to one so all we need is five grand.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: I would rather put my money on a three-legged rocking horse. The odds are a hundred to one for a good reason, BACON . . . it won't win. So where is Ed with all the bright ideas?

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: At the bottom of a bottle and has been for two days; it's hit him hard.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: It's hit us all hard!

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Yeah, but he has got to tell his Dad he is about to lose his bar.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Drachmas, I hope. I would feel safer with a chicken drumstick. They could do more harm than good.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Jesus, Tom, do they work?

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Ed can run fast, talk fast, eat fast, and play cards fast, but he's fucking slow when it comes to spotting the roz.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: The reason he is called BACON is he spent so much of his youth in the police station that people thought he was one of them. But he is a big boy now and it is time to move on.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Hatchet has a colleague, a monster of a man: Barry the Baptist.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: The Baptist got his name from drowning people for Hatchet.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Twenty-five from me, Tom, Soap and yourself; a hundred grand to the pound. You don't need to count it.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: I still will, if you don't mind.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Because it's cheap like a budgie.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: And nobody wants to live next door to the people that we live next to; a bit anti-social, you know.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Let me tell you about Hatchet Harry. Once there was this geezer called Smithy Robinson who worked for Harry. It was rumoured that he was on the take. Harry invited Smithy round for an explanation. Smithy didn't do a very good job. Within a minute Harry lost his temper and reached for the nearest thing at hand, which happened to be a fifteen-inch black rubber cock. He then proceeded to batter poor Smithy to death with this; that was seen as a pleasant way to go . . . Hence, Hatchet Harry is a man you pay if you owe.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: I'll think of something, don't worry.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: I don't know how you've reached that conclusion.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: They can't report they have had all their drugs and money nicked, can they?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: It's happening tomorrow morning. Get back here now.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Of course you will, sweetheart. This one, search this one. Ed finds the keys without any trouble.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: I'll meet you in the van when you have finished with handsome there.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Bacon, see what we got.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Let's have a butcher's. Jesus, there's lots of everything. We've got god knows how much of this stinking weed; we've got a shit load of cash; and we've got a . . . traffic warden.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: I think he's still alive. He's got claret coming out of him somewhere. What did they want with a traffic warden?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: I dunno, but I don't think we need him. Dump him at the lights.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Scarface, I have watched Scarface. You want to know how to do a drug deal, you watch Scarface!

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: That inspires confidence, that does.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: He'll care all right. That was going to be his money. Whether he cares about us is different. Pass your phone.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Think about what you're going to say, Ed; we are on thin ice.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Well what?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: The traffic warden went to the morgue and recognized Dog and his lot so that put us sort of in the clear. They got no case against us because there is no evidence against us.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Apart from those shotguns.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: And Tom took care of them.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: SAMOAN JO
turns.text: A cocktail, you asked for a cocktail.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: No, I asked you to give me a refreshing drink. I wasn't expecting a fucking rainforest; you could fall in love with an orang-utan in that.

turns.speaker: SAMOAN JO
turns.text: You want a pint, go to the pub.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: I thought this was a pub.

turns.speaker: SAMOAN JO
turns.text: It's a Samoan pub.

turns.speaker: BACON
turns.text: Well whatever it is, could you get your man to turn the TV down?

turns.speaker: SAMOAN JO
turns.text: You ask him if you like, but I would leave him to it if I was you.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Like antiques.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: Antiques? What the fuck do we know about antiques? We rob post offices and steal cars, what the fuck do we know about antiques?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: If it looks old, it's worth money, simple. So stop fucking moaning and rob the place.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: I thought you said no staff, Bazza!

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: You get the guns?

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: You should see what they did to poor Gary.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: Next time we do a job like this we gonna want more money, or we are going back to post offices and cars.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Where're the others?

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: There are no others.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Now, stop fucking around. The others, the old ones?

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: I don't know what you mean.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: There were two old guns there; where are they?

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: Not in the cabinet there wasn't. There was a couple of old hammer-lock muskets the butler was carrying; they were ours, and we sold 'em!

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Well you just better un-sell 'em, sharpish.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: They were . . .

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: I am not fucking interested.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: You fucking well have to get 'em!

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: We made a deal for everything inside the cabinet.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Inside, out-fuckin'-side. I don't give a shit, you get those guns because if you don't . . .

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: Yeah, Bazza, what?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: You heard of Harry Lonsdale? Otherwise known as Back-you-up with-a- Hatchet Harry, infamous for his removal of digits?

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: All right, all right, so we can say he is good.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Better than good, he is a fucking liability.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: Where did he get a hundred grand?

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: And JD is his dad, and owns the whole property?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: No mortgage, no debts; lock, stock, the sodding lot . . . don't worry, I got it under control.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: Good, you can get this under control now.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Er, very nice Harry. What's it for?

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: Don't play innocent with me Bazza; spanking!

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Shotguns? What, like guns that fire shot?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Oh, you must be the brains then. That's right, guns that fire shot . . . Make sure you bring everything from inside the gun cabinet. There will be a load of guns, that's all I want. I'll pay you when you deliver. Everything outside the cabinet you can keep; it's yours.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Oh, thanks very much. And there had better be something there for us.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: It's a fucking stately home, of course there'll be something there.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: So who's the Guv? Who we doing this for?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: You're doing it for me is all you need to know. You only know that because you need to know.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: I see, one of those `on a need to know' basis things, like a James Bond film, is it?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Careful, remember who's giving you this job.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: I hate these Southern shites.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Fucking Northern monkeys.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: JD.

turns.speaker: JD
turns.text: Chris.  You come to collect something, Chris? Should I have something for you?

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: JD
turns.text: Can I help?

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: I think I can help you, as it happens.

turns.speaker: JD
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: I have got something for ya. Well, for your boy, actually.

turns.speaker: JD
turns.text: Well, I suggest you speak to him, then.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: It's about time you give my young friends a visit, Chris. Tomorrow is the day and mum seems to be the word, and I can't have that now, can I, Chris?

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: No Harry, you can't.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: The boys had 'em. I know you like these things; wondered if you wanted them?

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: Er, yeah, sure, I'll have 'em.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: Have you counted the money?

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah, it's all there, to the pound.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: They were going to pay, then?

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: It looks like ít, but who knows? The opportunity was there. In my experience it is best to take the opportunity if it is there.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: Good job, Chris.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Mind your language in front of my boy.

turns.speaker: JOHN O'DRISCOLL
turns.text: Jesus Christ!

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Did I say speak? And it's Mr Harry to you . . . Now don't disappoint me and chose your words carefully. You may speak.

turns.speaker: JOHN O'DRISCOLL
turns.text: I'll have it for Mr Harry in a few days. I have been busy, and I am nearly there.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Son, have a look in his locker.

turns.speaker: JOHN O'DRISCOLL
turns.text: No chance of you lifting this sunbed up is there?

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Hello, John. Nice holiday?

turns.speaker: JOHN O'DRISCOLL
turns.text: I won't be seeing you again Chris; I have paid him every last penny.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: I am sure you have, no one was accusing you of being dishonest, John.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Son?

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Made a few quid, did ya? Now where is it?

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: You all right back there, mate?

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Very fucking funny. Where's what I want?

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: It's in an office; I have just left it in the office. 137

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Well, you had better go and get it from the office. That's if you want to see your son reach his next birthday. Now chop-fuckin'-chop.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: All right, furry muff.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Well, it's a five minute walk or a thirty second drive.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: You had better be careful.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: How long has he been in there, son?

turns.speaker: LITTLE CHRIS
turns.text: About twenty minutes.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Is he on his own?

turns.speaker: LITTLE CHRIS
turns.text: Just carrying a bag.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Let's have a look, shall we?

turns.speaker: LITTLE CHRIS
turns.text: It's not him, Dad.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Try that one.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: That should take care of that lot. We are now officially in the money- loaning business, all right, son?

turns.speaker: LITTLE CHRIS
turns.text: All right, Dad.

turns.speaker: BIG CHRIS
turns.text: Well, put your seatbelt on then.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: That's no way to answer the phone.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Is that you, Dean?

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: Sure is.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: You know those shotguns I sold ya, well I need 'em back.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Not likely I am afraid; I don't think I'll be seeing them again.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: I got the money to pay for 'em.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I am sure you do, but I don't think you understand; I am not going to see them or the guns again.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: OK Gary, we call each other Kenny, all right?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: All right, Kenny.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: Can't you pull that stocking down further, Kenny?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: It just cost me fifty quid to have this done.  If you think I am going to ruin it for a couple of old bastards you're mistaken, Kenny.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Who was that?

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: That was Hatchet Horrible Harry.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Jesus, I have heard about him.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: We're in the spite. They were his fucking guns that we sold; we gotta find 'em.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: We gotta get those guns.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: This is dangerous shit, Dean; we don't even know who lives in there.

turns.speaker: DEAN
turns.text: Listen, I don't care who lives in there; all as I know it's got to be preferable to death by Hatchet.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Furry muff, let's go.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: I want you to search the house for bugs. I mean I want you to strip it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What is the point in that? Even if it was a bug they would have taken it with 'em.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: It is too late for you to start thinking John. It is a possibility and that is good enough for me. And after you strip the house, I want you to get every thieving slag this side of Ceylon and torture them, badly. I want to know who is responsible, otherwise I will hold you responsible.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: So we have a bit of a problem, don't we?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Er well, yes we do.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: In fact it is a little more than a bit of a problem, isn't it? You could say that in the scale of these things this is the Mount fucking Everest of problems, couldn't you? . . . And the reason it is such a mon fucking-strosity of a problem is because you don't have the first fucking idea who did this to us, do you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Dog, I have found the cash!

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: The stupid bastards! Count it!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Shit, Dog, there's a lot. Don't you want to do this next door?

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: We're not going next door until we've flayed these dead men walking. Count it out the back. I don't want them seeing you fingering that money as soon as they walk in.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: But...  Give it us here, you dozy sod. You hide and get the guns ready. Wait until they are well in, then give it to 'em.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: So do you know these geezers well?

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: Well enough. I have been buying gear off one of them for a couple of years.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: What they like then?

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: Poofs. Nothing heavy, four public school guys. Soft as shite.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: There's one steel gate as you go in but they never lock it.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: What do you mean, never? Well what have they got it for, then?

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: I must have been there fifty times, it's never been locked; they're not suspicious. Everybody who goes there are toffs. They're all into that karma crap: `If I don't harm nobody, nobody harms me' stuff.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Is there no way they can get back to you?

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: Even if they could they'd be too shit scared. They have got no muscle; they're gutless faggots.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: There's nothing to worry about, it's going to be easy.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: There is no such thing as easy in my experience and, if you think this is going to be easy, you're a dick. It may be easier than most but it's not going to be easy.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: What's that idiot doing next door?  We use your van. It's up some stairs this place, so we'll stick out like balls on a bulldog. Plank is going up first. There is a cage but it is never locked, is it Plank?

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: And it better bloody not be. Once he is firmly in place, he gets the rest of us in. We'll get nasty with a couple of them, shit 'em up, scare and gag 'em. I can't see these wankers giving us a problem, but they might have a couple of tools hanging around like any cowboy. When the job is done we'll come straight back here. It's dark by then, unload and Robert's your father's brother. Everybody savvy?

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: Just hold on, I got the keys.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: What the fuck did you do to Fauntleroy?

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: I didn't touch him, he just passed out.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: It must be this one.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Just give me the keys.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: Don't you stags move or I'll kill the lot of ya.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Who are you going to kill Plank? There's no one there.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: Yeah, one of them's out.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: OK, open the gate.

turns.speaker: PLANK
turns.text: My neck, Dog.  That's the last bag?

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: How about you? All right?

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Willy, this is the last time, and don't let him know that you're here, otherwise he will be here all day, and get rid of him quick. We have work to do.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: What the fuck is going on?

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: J, what's going on out there?  Get the rifle out, Charles. We're being fucked.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Get the sodding gate open now, Plank.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Right, his leg's going now.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: All right, all fucking right, I am coming.  Willie, he doesn't know you are here, just sort something out, OK.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: And all your friends, there's a good lad.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: There is only three of us here.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Do you want me to take his leg off? Where's the fourth?

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: I mean it, there is only three of us here.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Plank?

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Out the back.

turns.speaker: DOG
turns.text: And the weed?

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Out the back.

turns.speaker: DOORMAN
turns.text: Invitations.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Invitations?

turns.speaker: DOORMAN
turns.text: Yeah invitations, you know a pretty white piece of paper with your name on it.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Well we have got about a hundred thousand pretty pieces of paper with the Queen on it. Will that do?

turns.speaker: DOORMAN
turns.text: All right, just you; the others can wait in Samoan Jo's next door.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Samoan Jo's? Yon mean the pub? Hold on . . .

turns.speaker: DOORMAN
turns.text: Hold on bollocks, no one but card players in here tonight sonny, and I do mean no one.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Are you sure you can afford twenty-five?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Well that depends on how you look at it. I can afford it as long as I see it again, if that's what you mean. You got the rest from the fat man and Bacon?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Well, what do you want us to do about it?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Hit the fuckers.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: What was that, armed? What do you mean, armed? Armed with what?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Er, bad breath, colourful language and a feather duster! . . . What do you think they will be armed with? Guns, you tit!

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Guns! You never said anything about guns. A minute ago this was the safest job in the world, now it's turning in to a bad day in Bosnia . . .

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Jesus, Soap, stop being such a mincer. I thought about that and...

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: And we will just have to find out who's going to be carrying them.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Carrying them. They could all be carrying them for what we know.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: No, just one of them is in charge of them going to the job. So I assume he will still

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Where the fuck are they going? To butcher a sheep? I thought this was a robbery.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Where did they get those outfits from? Haven't we got some like that, Tom?

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: No I fucking don't! You can't make a cup of tea, Edward.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Why not? The whole of the British Empire was built on cups of tea.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: And look what happened to that.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: If you think I am going to war without one, you're mistaken, mate.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: That's it all done, we are off.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: You think it's a good idea taking it back to yours?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: There is nowhere else to keep it, and it's the last place they are going to look. Anyway the battle's over and the war is won.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: I hope this is the right move.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: It's either that, my old boy's place, and we lose a digit daily. I am going to call him.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: You what? What are you on about?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Listen, if he has the guns he might have the money . . . I think we should go and see him.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: Well, what's going on?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: I don't know, but what I do know is that there's no more Harry, which means there's no more debt, and if there's no more debt there's no more problem, and there's no more problem with our neighbours because they are all dead. I think, if I get this right, we haven't done anything wrong anyway, which means we are in the clear.

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: I don't think we will take the risk for seven hundred quid.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Tom, go and throw those guns off a bridge.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: There's nothing in it!

turns.speaker: SOAP
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: I mean it's fucking empty.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Who's this fat man, then?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Bacon, the fat man and myself, and it's time to make a call to Harry.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You see it's not easy to take a seat at this table; the money involved has to be a hundred grand upwards and there is no shortage of punters.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: The man who decides if you can play is this man Harry, or Hatchet Harry as some including himself like to call him.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: He means they're thieving dogs.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What the hell are you doing here?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Why, what's up?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Er, let me guess, my foot in your arse? A game of cards and Hatchet Harry. You're supposed to be getting some rest, boy!

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I dunno, but they look nice. I rather like ' em.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Top of the list of priorities, how nice they look.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Everything all right out there, Tom?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Right as rain.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Where the hell are we supposed to hide?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, what did he say?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: He said he thinks we have paid him, and he wants to talk about those guns . . . now.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: You and me, Tom.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What do you mean, me?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Tom, this is our case.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: . . . What?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: This is our money, Tom! . . . Now I think we should go.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Tom, don't mess around, let's go.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I'11 meet you in the car.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Tom?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I'll only be a minute.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: The only item that connects us with the crime is sitting in your car which is sitting outside?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: We paid seven hundred quid for those guns. They could hardly trace them to you, could they?

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: You got it all?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: A hundred grand.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: You must be Eddy. JD's son.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Yup, you must be Harry? Sorry, I didn't know your father.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: Never mind son, you just might meet him if you carry on like that.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: That is quite a raise, one hundred and fifty on my hundred.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: Yes . . . and is there something else you want to say? EDDY

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: I will.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: You will what?

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: I will loan you the money.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: I think I would rather just turn them over.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: I am not interested in what you would rather; I want to keep going. I am also offering you the money, so we don't have to turn them over because you can borrow.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: I need two hundred and fifty grand.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: No, you need five hundred grand to see me.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: That's if I want to see you.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: Well, you're going to have a problem carrying on, aintcha.

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: I'll see ya.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: For half a million?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: Unless you are going to accept twenty quid.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: And still got a sense of humour. That's not monkey nuts son; you can still fold.  OK, before I loan you this, I expect, if you lose of course, my money back within a week, Crystal? That's Sunday, OK?

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: That you, boy?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: It's Ed, if that's what you mean.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: It's pay day, ain't it?

turns.speaker: EDDY
turns.text: I wanted to talk to you about that.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: I bet you did. I have got half a million nicker sitting in front of me, which means that some poor sod doesn't. You must have upset a few people, boy . . . but that isn't really my concern, is it? But what does concern me is the guns you had. I want to talk to you about that. Get your arse over here now, and I do mean now!

turns.speaker: JD
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: I like your bar.

turns.speaker: JD
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: I want your bar.

turns.speaker: JD
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: Do you want me to draw a picture?

turns.speaker: JD
turns.text: Harry, that boy doesn't know his arsehole from his ear-hole, or you from a hoodwink. This bar is mine, and he has nothing to do with it.

turns.speaker: HATCHET
turns.text: What, and I care? Remember, you do have the luxurious advantage of being able to sustain your son's life.

turns.speaker: JD
turns.text: And you do have a reputation, so I'll choose my words carefully. But not to put too fine a point on it, fuck yourself, Harry!
